author: By Constant Méheut, Kim Barker and Maria Varenikova
title: Cajole, Plead and Flatter: Ukraine Makes Its Case to Trump
description: Using diplomacy, flattery and the occasional shot in the dark, Ukraine is doing everything it can to win over President-elect Donald J. Trump to its side.
content: From desperate stabs at diplomacy to fanciful expressions of flattery, Ukrainian officials are doing everything they can to bring President-elect Donald J. Trump into their corner as they try to strengthen their position in the war against Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Merissa Marr
title: What Does Rupert Murdoch Do Now?
description: “I love each of my children,” said the patriarch. “But these companies need a designated leader.”
content: In the final season of “Succession,” the HBO drama about a fictional media clan, the show’s grisly patriarch, Logan Roy, dishes out some characteristically choice words to his privileged children: “I love you, but you are not serious people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: The Joy of Bundling Up
description: As winter approaches, strolls around Central Park offer a leisurely way to take in the festive and cozy attire of the season.
content: The storybook holiday season in New York brings a certain coziness to Central Park, even as the landscape’s palette fades from autumnal reds, oranges and yellows to muted greens and browns. Stroll around and you are likely to spot telltale signs of wintertime in the city: couples bundled up for a long walk, families dressed to ice-skate, tourists looking for landmarks and tiny nooks featured in films like “Home Alone 2: Lost in New York.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump’s Transition Business Largely Happens After Night Falls
description: At his Mar-a-Lago club in Florida, the president-elect has been hosting diplomatic dinners, announcing cabinet picks and firing off texts to his aides — all after the sun goes down.
content: It was past midnight in Florida this week when President-elect Donald J. Trump decided to mock Justin Trudeau on social media, calling the prime minister of America’s neighbor the “governor” of “the Great State of Canada.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: The Trump Show Is Returning. Will It Be Triumph, Tragedy or Farce?
description: TV has fixated on one person, as news, comedy material and dramatic subtext, since 2015. Can it do another four years?
content: On his last show before Election Day, John Oliver allowed himself to dream a little dream. Mr. Oliver, whose “Last Week Tonight” speaks to a mostly left-of-center crowd, spent most of the episode making the case for Kamala Harris. But also, he asked his audience, wouldn’t it be nice, for the first time since 2015, to have the option of simply ignoring Donald J. Trump’s existence? “I want so badly to live in that world!” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun, Jin Yu Young and Victoria Kim
title: South Korea’s President Is Impeached After Martial Law Crisis
description: Some members of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s own party helped remove him from office. But the political uncertainty is far from over.
content: Eleven days ago, President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea made a bold power grab, putting the country under military rule for the first time in 45 years, citing frustration at the opposition for obstructing his agenda in Parliament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,275
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Dec. 15, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Steven Erlanger
title: U.S. in Direct Contact With Rebels Who Took Over Syria
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said the United States was communicating directly with Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, the dominant rebel faction, despite its designation as a terrorist group.
content: The United States has been in direct contact with the Syrian rebel group Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, which overthrew the dictatorship of Bashar al-Assad a week ago, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu and Jonah Markowitz
title: Dancing in the Park: How an M.T.A. Worker Spreads Joy
description: For eight years, Anthony Johnson has danced to Soca and disco music in Prospect Park in Brooklyn. He has a loyal following.
content: Even in New York City, where more than eight million people are largely accustomed to sticking to themselves and often expect the worst from each other, it’s possible to build a relationship with a stranger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: My Apartment Is Way Too Cold! How Do I Make the Landlord Fix It?
description: If your rental is not properly heated, gather your neighbors and complain together.
content: Q: We live in one of many Manhattan market-rate prewar rental buildings owned by a real estate family. We always had enough heat. Then the family hired a third-party management company. Now, a new heating system provides the legal minimum of 68.2 degrees of heat. At times, the heat rises, but not for very long. We are miserably cold. Many tenants here and elsewhere have complained. What can we do without provoking management retaliation? We fear our lease won’t be renewed if we speak up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: Why Democrats Lost More Seats in Vermont Than Any Other State
description: Even though Kamala Harris easily won the state, voters ousted more than two dozen Democratic legislators, who they felt had not addressed an affordability crisis.
content: It was no surprise that most voters in Vermont rejected Donald J. Trump on Election Day, favoring Vice President Kamala Harris by a margin of more than 30 points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Trump Has Little Room for Error
description: How Trump might cut short his political honeymoon.
content: The annals of American political history are littered with the remains of once-great presidential mandates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden Administration Is Said to Allow California to Ban New Gas-Powered Cars
description: California and 11 other states want to halt the sale of new gas-powered cars by 2035. President-elect Donald Trump is expected to try to stop them.
content: The Biden administration is expected in the coming days to grant California and 11 other states permission to ban the sale of new gasoline-powered cars by 2035, one of the most ambitious climate policies in the United States and beyond, according to three people briefed on the matter, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss it publicly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Sarah Kessler
title: Sam Altman on Microsoft, Trump and Musk
description: The OpenAI C.E.O. spoke with Andrew Ross Sorkin at the DealBook Summit.
content: Since kicking off the artificial intelligence boom with the launch of ChatGPT in 2022, OpenAI has amassed more than 300 million weekly users and a $157 billion valuation. Its C.E.O., Sam Altman, addressed whether that staggering pace of growth can continue at the DealBook Summit last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Postal Strike Means Fewer Gifts Under Canadian Christmas Trees
description: For many remote communities in the sparsely populated nation, Canada Post is the only parcel delivery option. Even Amazon relies on it.
content: Every Christmas season, Elizabeth Teasdale sets aside an entire room in her house on Cape Breton Island in Nova Scotia to store presents for her family’s large holiday gathering. By now, 20 to 30 packages should be stashed away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Georgian Lawmakers Hand Presidency to Far-Right Former Soccer Star
description: The vote, boycotted by opposition parties in Parliament, sets up a standoff with the sitting president and deepens turmoil in the country after protests and a disputed election.
content: Georgia’s governing lawmakers handed the presidency to a former soccer star turned far-right politician on Saturday, setting up a standoff with the sitting president and deepening the country’s political turmoil after weeks of protests and a disputed parliamentary election.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Europeans Eye Giving Syrians A Nudge Home
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 14, 2024.
content: “When I was born, that statue was there, and I’ve been wanting to remove it my entire life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maxim Loskutoff
title: The Unabomber’s Influence Is Deeper and More Dangerous Than We Know
description: To some disaffected young Americans, the ruthlessly intellectualized turn to violence can seem justified. It is not.
content: I published a novel about the Unabomber this year, and during a book tour stop in Seattle, a high school teacher raised his hand and asked me what he could tell his students about Ted Kaczynski, because he was a hero to so many of them. The question stopped me cold, reminding me that Mr. Kaczynski’s influence is deeper and more widespread than most people realize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: The Impeachment of South Korea’s President, Explained
description: In its second attempt, the National Assembly moved to force President Yoon Suk Yeol from office. But the troubles for him and his country are far from over.
content: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s short-lived declaration of martial law has created South Korea’s biggest constitutional crisis since the country democratized in the late 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Wu
title: An Art World Satire Invokes a (Literal) Ghost
description: In Ella Baxter’s novel “Woo Woo,” a feminist performance artist starts to question herself on the eve of a provocative solo exhibition.
content: Sabine Rossi is a week out from the opening of her solo art exhibition at a gallery in Melbourne, Australia, at the start of Ella Baxter’s second novel, “Woo Woo.” Each of the show’s 15 photographs depicts the artist in a costume comprising the mask of a female archetype and a sheer “skin” — a “wearable puppet” — that sheathes her body without concealing it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: The Message: Impeach South Korea’s President. The Tune: ‘Feliz Navidad.’
description: Baek Jae Gil, whose viral anthem calls for the ouster of President Yoon Suk Yeol, has a long history with the country’s pro-democracy movement.
content: While calling for President Yoon Suk Yeol’s removal, tens of thousands of South Korean protesters have danced to traditional percussion, sung a pop genre called trot and blasted “Whiplash,” a hit by the girl group Aespa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carmilla Floyd and Joseph Rodriguez
title: How Sweden Could End Its Epidemic of Gang Violence
description: We know that tough-on-crime policies for children have been tried repeatedly elsewhere and have failed. So why is my country headed that way?
content: We used to believe in Sweden that the rights and well-being of children should always come first. But over the past two decades, a surge in gang violence has shaken that commitment. In 2023, 363 shootings took the lives of 53 people; this year, over 100 bombings stemming from gang violence had already been recorded by November. Our country now has one of the highest per capita rates of gun violence in the European Union. One key factor in the phenomenon: Gangs are grooming and recruiting children as young as 11, the police say, as contract killers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Argentina’s President Receives Italian Citizenship, Angering Law’s Critics
description: Javier Milei is proud of his Italian ancestry and has tried to bolster ties with Italy’s conservative prime minister. But his new passport angered critics of Italy’s rules on citizenship.
content: When President Javier Milei of Argentina stepped onto the grounds of Giorgia Meloni’s party festival at Rome’s Circus Maximus, a conservative fair that mixed holiday and Italy-First energy, he found a skating rink, a Christmas tree and an upbeat, anti-woke crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Applying Psychotherapy to Heal Our Political Divide
description: Readers respond to an essay by a couples therapist.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vaughn Vreeland
title: Sweet Season
description: The holidays are upon us. It’s time to start baking.
content: Cookie hive, assemble. Why? Because it’s the most wonderful time of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Children’s Tennis Instructor Spends Her Sundays
description: Joyce Short, who has worked with New York Junior Tennis and Learning for decades, takes a popcorn break in between classes, and plays pickleball with friends.
content: Joyce Short, 77, has survived many things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Isak Andic, Founder of Mango Fashion Chain, Dies at 71
description: Mr. Andic got his start by selling T-shirts in Barcelona in the mid-1980s. He died in a fall during a hike.
content: Isak Andic, who built the fashion brand Mango from a Spanish storefront into a global giant with more than 2,000 stores on five continents, died in a fall while hiking near Barcelona on Saturday. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ionova and María Magdalena Arréllaga
title: A Surprise Blockbuster in Brazil Stokes Oscar Hopes, and a Reckoning
description: Decades after her mother missed out on an Oscar, Brazil’s Fernanda Torres may have a chance to win a golden statuette with a role in a film that has set off deep soul-searching.
content: Fernanda Torres still remembers the day her mother, Brazil’s grande dame of film, came within reach of cinema’s most coveted prize: an Oscar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Can We Make Pop Culture Great Again?
description: Worrying that even if the rest of American society starts moving, our storytelling is still going to be stuck.
content: When “Wicked” and “Gladiator II” debuted together late last month, there was a painful attempt to call their shared box office success “Glicked” — a reference to the portmanteau of “Barbenheimer” that described the joint cultural triumph of “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” in the summer of 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas and Dayana Iwaza
title: Hezbollah Loses Supply Route Through Syria, in Blow to It and Iran
description: The militant group’s leader admits that the toppling of Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, cut off an important land route from Iran.
content: The leader of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah acknowledged on Saturday that its supply route through Syria had been cut off by rebels who toppled the government last weekend, dealing another blow to Hezbollah and its patron, Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: An Artist Who Has Something in Common With Her Subjects
description: Rachel Handlin is possibly the first person with Down syndrome to receive an M.F.A., and one of just a few to hold a bachelor’s. Her first solo show features her portraits of others like her.
content: On the evening in early November when I met the artist Rachel Handlin at White Columns, the prestigious nonprofit gallery in the West Village, she immediately outstretched her arms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Are Childhood Vaccines ‘Overloading’ the Immune System? No.
description: Vaccines today are more efficient and contain far fewer stimulants to the immune system than some used decades ago.
content: It’s an idea as popular as it is incorrect: American babies now receive too many vaccines, which overwhelm their immune systems and lead to conditions like autism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Fatima AbdulKarim
title: Palestinian Authority Deploys Security Forces Against Militants in West Bank
description: The authority, which has struggled to crack down on powerful armed groups in the territory, is under pressure from the United States to escalate law-and-order operations.
content: The Palestinian Authority announced an unusually public crackdown on militants in the Israeli-occupied West Bank on Saturday, sending armored vehicles through a city’s streets and engaging in gun battles with armed groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Moody’s Downgrades France’s Credit Rating, Citing Political Turmoil
description: The action, which will put pressure on the nation’s borrowing costs, reflects doubt that a new government can mend the deteriorating financial situation.
content: In a surprise announcement, Moody’s rating agency downgraded France’s debt rating early Saturday, hours after President Emmanuel Macron appointed a new prime minister in a bid to stabilize a government that has been rocked by months of political turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Strong Storm Brings a Rarity in San Francisco: A Tornado Warning
description: Less than two weeks after a tsunami warning, residents were jolted awake before 6 a.m. to consider a new potential disaster scenario.
content: Powerful storms swept through parts of Northern California on Saturday, knocking down trees, causing widespread power outages and prompting weather officials to issue what they said was the first-ever tornado warning for San Francisco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: To Dial Down Campus Tensions, Colleges Teach the Art of Conversation
description: Dialogue is an essential part of college. As anger over the war in the Middle East has brought upheaval to campuses, it has also become a key way schools try to reduce conflict.
content: On a warm November day, a group of Columbia University professors set up “listening tables” near the center of campus and hailed students rushing to class, inviting them to stop and talk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: In Display of Fealty, Tech Industry Curries Favor With Trump
description: It was a week of frenzied activity, as Silicon Valley billionaires and their companies brandished checks and compliments for the President-elect.
content: The $1 million donations came gradually — and then all at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: A.T.F. Braces for a Likely Rollback of Its Gun-Control Efforts
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump is almost certain to choose a gun-rights advocate as director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives or to simply leave the job vacant.
content: Many federal agencies are bracing for the Trump era — but few are likely to face the powerful backlash that awaits the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, which pursued an aggressive gun control agenda under President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Gerd Heidemann, Journalist Duped by Fake Hitler Diaries, Dies at 93
description: What was supposed to be the crowning scoop of his career became his downfall when a trove of notebooks he acquired in Germany turned out to be forgeries.
content: Gerd Heidemann, a globe-trotting, high-flying German journalist who thought he had landed the scoop of the century — the private diaries of Adolf Hitler — but who came crashing back to earth after they were exposed as crude forgeries, died on Monday at a hospital in Hamburg, Germany. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ionova
title: Brazilian Police Arrest Close Ally of Ex-President Bolsonaro, Official Says
description: Gen. Walter Braga Netto was Jair Bolsonaro’s running mate. The arrest was for meddling in an investigation into a plot to stage a coup, the police said.
content: Brazilian police on Saturday arrested Gen. Walter Braga Netto, a close ally of former President Jair Bolsonaro and his running mate in 2022, according to a police official, accusing him of meddling in their investigation into a plot to stage a coup after Mr. Bolsonaro lost the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Richard Gere Calls ‘Blonde on Blonde’ His All-Time Favorite
description: “He’s our Picasso,” the actor said of Bob Dylan.
content: It has been more than four decades since an Armani-clad Richard Gere slunk around Los Angeles in Paul Schrader’s “American Gigolo.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Is There a Better $600 Investment?
description: Women with obstetric fistulas suffer year after year, even as a $619 surgery can restore them.
content: One of the most dangerous things a woman can do in much of the world is become pregnant, and the risks caught up with a Kenyan named Alice Wanjiru a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Personal Data of Rhode Island Residents Breached in Large Cyberattack
description: An “international cybercriminal group” harvested the personal data of potentially hundreds of thousands of people from the state’s social services and health insurance systems, officials said.
content: The personal and private information of possibly hundreds of thousands of people who applied for government assistance in Rhode Island could be in the hands of hackers after a huge cyberattack, state officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: C.E.O.’s Killing Poses Early Test for New N.Y.P.D. Commissioner
description: Weeks ago, Jessica Tisch was in charge of street sweeping and trash pickup. On Monday, she found herself overseeing a ferocious manhunt as the head of the Police Department.
content: Jessica S. Tisch, New York’s police commissioner, was giving her two sons their morning cereal on Dec. 4 when she got a text from a deputy telling her that the chief executive of UnitedHealthcare had been shot dead on a Manhattan sidewalk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Degen
title: The Marketing Hurricane of ‘Wicked’ Says a Lot About Our Culture
description: The movie’s marketing push, involving 400 brand tie-ins, shows how our culture has become littered with formulaic and meaningless collaborations.
content: Even before “Wicked” opened, the movie’s signature green and pink colors were turning up everywhere, from drinks topped with matcha foam at Starbucks to aisles lined with merch at Target. This cultural bludgeoning was, of course, orchestrated. Today, not even large marketing budgets can achieve such ubiquity without help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J Wortham
title: Another New Twitter? Good Luck With That.
description: Users are now flocking to Bluesky. But every social media platform becomes a wasteland in the end.
content: Recently, while talking to a friend who used to run a large media website, I casually mentioned the rise of Bluesky. More than a million users have deleted their X (formerly Twitter) accounts and moved over to the upstart social media site, which they see as a healthier replacement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Louise Snyder
title: The Menendez Brothers’ Case Challenges the Limits of Our Understanding of Abuse
description: Society knows more about abuse now, but it may not matter to the judicial system.
content: Recently, a Los Angeles judge delayed a hearing for Erik and Lyle Menendez in their bid to be resentenced for the murder of their parents 35 years ago. Renewed interest in the brothers’ case, fueled by Netflix’s recent docudrama series and documentary on the brothers, has drawn celebrity advocates to call for their release, alongside an army of TikTok accounts. Unfortunately for the brothers, social advocacy rarely corresponds to judicial change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: 4 Mysteries Shot Through With Malice and Grief
description: Our columnist on the month’s best new releases.
content: Pek’s debut “The Verifiers” was the book I most wanted to review in 2022, but didn’t. It wasn’t perfect, but I admired the fresh, sweetly sardonic voice of the amateur sleuth and mystery-novel aficionado Claudia Lin, as well as the way Pek raised questions about living, dating and lying online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nostrant
title: Robert Fernandez, Who Survived Pearl Harbor as a Teen, Dies at 100
description: He was a 17-year-old sailor aboard the U.S.S. Curtiss when Japanese forces attacked. He said he had joined the Navy to see the world.
content: Robert Fernandez, one of the last known American survivors of the bombing of Pearl Harbor, died on Wednesday in Lodi, Calif., just days after the 83rd anniversary of the attack. He was 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Brings Hegseth to Watch Army-Navy Game
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump made a public show of support for his choice to lead the Defense Department.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump attended the annual Army-Navy football game in Maryland on Saturday with Pete Hegseth, his embattled choice for defense secretary, sending a message of support ahead of Senate confirmation hearings that are likely to take place next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: No Evidence Drones in Northeast Are a Threat, Officials Say
description: Numerous sightings of flying objects in recent weeks have raised alarm, but federal law enforcement officials say that at least some were manned aircraft, such as airplanes or helicopters.
content: After reviewing thousands of tips, federal law enforcement officials on Saturday reaffirmed that mysterious drones spotted in the Northeast in recent weeks pose no national security threat and in most cases are not even drones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: Joy and Celebrations in Seoul for Protesters as Yoon Is Impeached
description: “Long live South Korea!” demonstrators chanted, describing a wave of relief after days of anger over the president’s surprise declaration of martial law.
content: Braving the cold, the protesters seeking President Yoon Suk Yeol’s ouster had gathered in the thousands on Saturday outside South Korea’s National Assembly, where lawmakers were to decide whether to impeach the leader. The crowd was boisterous in its insistence: “Impeach Yoon!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Timothée Chalamet Dresses Like Bob Dylan at ‘A Complete Unknown’ New York Premiere
description: The actor also joined Elle Fanning and Edward Norton — stars of a new film tracing the musician’s ascent — for an after-party at the Chelsea Hotel.
content: “I saw him,” said Charlotte Barbié, 18, who stood outside the SVA Theater on Friday night, shaking from either the cold or the excitement. “He was blond.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: As the Right Lionizes Daniel Penny, His Prosecutor Faces a Familiar Fury
description: Alvin Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney who won a conviction of Donald J. Trump, has been a target of the right. After Mr. Penny’s acquittal in a subway choking, Mr. Bragg faces fresh anger.
content: Daniel Penny broke into a smile at midmorning Monday, hugging both of his lawyers in a Manhattan courtroom and getting a kiss on the cheek from one. Moments before, a jury forewoman had said Mr. Penny was not guilty of criminally negligent homicide in the death of a homeless subway passenger he had restrained in a chokehold last year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Art of the Gift: Julio Torres
description: “A good gift is like a bridge between two people,” the creator of “Los Espookys” said. “It’s a way of communicating, ‘You are on my mind when you’re not in front of me.’”
content: Known for his surrealist comedy, the El Salvador-born, Brooklyn-based performer Julio Torres, 37, is a former staff writer on “Saturday Night Live” and the co-creator of the HBO series “Los Espookys.” He most recently wrote, directed and starred in the film “Problemista” and the HBO series “Fantasmas.” This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: Rick Steves Refuses to Get Cynical About the World
description: The guidebook writer and television personality reflects on his cancer diagnosis, social media’s corrosive effect on tourism and the transformative power of travel.
content: In 1994, just after I graduated from college, I put on a backpack and set off to see the world. I climbed the Andes in Ecuador, taught English in Cambodia and spent months visiting monasteries in Tibet. It was the most transformative period of my life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Art Heist
description: David Kwong draws us in with a magical challenge.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Rare Cross-Canada Political Consensus Forms Against Trump’s Border Threat
description: Canadian leaders agreed to tighten the border, but not on how to respond if President-elect Donald J. Trump follows through on 25 percent tariffs.
content: On Monday, Chrystia Freeland, the finance minister and deputy prime minister, will present her much-delayed fall economic statement just in time for the holidays. And the government has promised that it will address the issue that preoccupied politicians this week: how to respond to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threat to impose potentially devastating 25 percent tariffs on exports to the United States from Canada and Mexico unless the two nations tighten their borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: U.S. Court Denies TikTok’s Request to Freeze Sale-or-Ban Law
description: TikTok had sought to temporarily freeze a law that requires its Chinese parent to sell the app or face a U.S. ban next month. The case may now head to the Supreme Court.
content: A federal court on Friday denied TikTok’s request to temporarily freeze a law that requires its Chinese parent company to sell the app or face a ban in the United States as of Jan. 19, a decision that puts the fate of the app in the Supreme Court’s hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Andreatta
title: Where It Isn’t Christmas Until the City Shoots Lasers at 20,000 Crows
description: In Rochester, N.Y., every year in early December thousands of crows descend on the city, which tries to shoo them away with loud noises and bright lights.
content: In Rochester, N.Y., there are telltale signs that the holiday season is underway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Tea Supplier
description: Owen Bergstein makes a proud debut.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is an excellent, sure-footed challenge from Owen Bergstein, a new constructor to The New York Times. There’s a lot of whimsy, but the cuteness is intertwined with tough stuff, too difficult to be saccharine. There are lots of odd expressions in the long entries, yes, but they really work on a Saturday. I have to tip my hat when I don’t know where an entry is going after I have six of 11 letters, for instance, and then find that the right answer is a commonplace reference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Pelosi Has Hip Replacement Surgery After Fall
description: The former speaker of the House “is well on the mend,” her spokesman said. She fell while in Luxembourg as part of a congressional delegation to mark the 80th anniversary of the Battle of the Bulge.
content: Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, had hip replacement surgery on Saturday after falling while on an official trip to Luxembourg, her office said in a statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: ‘Home Alone’ Hits the Road, With Macaulay Culkin. ‘Filthy Animals’ Cheer.
description: In Chicago, where the suburbs served as locations, a showing of the film featured an appearance by the star. Delighted fans made their devotion known.
content: It has been 34 years since Kevin McAllister paint-canned two sour-faced bandits in “Home Alone.” And every Christmas since, fans have taken self-made tours of suburban Chicago sites in the classic holiday movie, which finds 8-year-old Kevin defending himself against robbers after his family leaves for a vacation without him. The stately residence where exteriors were shot in Winnetka, Ill., is the area’s top tourist attraction, with thousands of visitors annually.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Daniel Berehulak
title: Syria Shudders as Assad’s Prison Atrocities Come Into the Light
description: At the country’s most notorious prison, Syrians confront their worst fears: that they will never know what happened to the loved ones who disappeared.
content: People came by the thousands the day after the rebels arrived in Damascus, racing down the once desolate stretch of road, up a jagged footpath cut into the limestone hillside and through the towering metal gates of Syria’s most notorious prison. They flooded the halls lined with cells, searching for loved ones who had disappeared into the black hole of torture prisons under Bashar al-Assad’s government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilaria Parogni and Chad Unger
title: Guggenheim Offers the Poetry of Motion: Sign Language Verses
description: The museum’s poet in residence for 2024 is putting poetry by deaf and hard-of-hearing artists on display.
content: Noah Buchholz, a deaf poet, was standing on a stage on the ground floor of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on Wednesday night, with a gentle smile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Sullivan
title: Here Comes the Bride (Just Not to That Song)
description: More couples are skipping the traditional processional to Richard Wagner’s “Bridal Chorus.”
content: When Becky Pedroza began planning her wedding, she imagined a celebration as vibrant and free-spirited as her relationship with Erik Revelli.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Thanks to a Prank, Sculptures Make Googly Eyes at Oregon Residents
description: The eyes were attached to eight installations, to the delight of residents. City officials, who lamented the cost of repairs, were less amused.
content: If you travel through Bend, Ore., and have the feeling that you’re being watched, it’s not a stroke of paranoia: Googly eyes were affixed to eight public art sculptures around the city, to the chagrin of some local officials but to the delight of many residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: In Port Labor Dispute, Trump Backed a Union That Courted Him
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump is supporting the International Longshoremen’s Association, which could strike soon if it doesn’t reach a deal on automation with employers.
content: Leaders of some labor unions tried to establish good relations with Donald J. Trump before the election — and for one of them, that effort may already be paying off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Alan Feuer
title: ABC to Pay $15 Million to Settle a Defamation Suit Brought by Trump
description: The outcome of the lawsuit marks an unusual victory for President-elect Donald J. Trump in his ongoing legal campaign against national news organizations.
content: ABC News is set to pay $15 million to settle a defamation lawsuit brought by Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 553
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Dec. 15, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: It’s Time for Nutella Tres Leches Cake
description: Though, to be fair, it’s hard to imagine a time when Rick Martínez’s chocolaty take on the classic dessert wouldn’t be welcome.
content: Nutella tres leches cake!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Barrett
title: Saving England’s Music Oasis From a New Wave of Development
description: The working-class city of Manchester has birthed legendary bands for decades. But in its quest for growth, its musical legacy is in danger of being muted.
content: Glass towers crowd the skyline in Manchester, encroaching a bit more each year on the legacy of this northern English city with a musical soul.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Vote For the Best Metropolitan Diary Entry of 2024
description: We will have published 250 Diary entries this year by the end of December. We need your help choosing the best. New York Times editors narrowed the field to five finalists. Now it’s up to you to vote for your favorite.
content: We will have published 250 Diary entries this year by the end of December. We need your help choosing the best. New York Times editors narrowed the field to five finalists. Now it’s up to you to vote for your favorite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Agnes Chang and Pablo Robles
title: How the President Alienated South Korea, One Group at a Time
description: Even before Yoon Suk Yeol’s fateful decree, the public had been infuriated with near-constant scandals and unpopular decisions since he took office.
content: Even before Yoon Suk Yeol’s fateful decree, the public had been infuriated with near-constant scandals and unpopular decisions since he took office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cassel, Alessandro Pavone, Sarah Kerr and Mark Boyer
title: Searching for Syria’s Disappeared
description: Taher al-Zain’s father disappeared 12 years ago at the height of Bashar al-Assad’s regime. Now, like thousands of other Syrians, he is trying to find clues about what happened, and whether or not his father may still be alive.
content: Taher al-Zain’s father disappeared 12 years ago at the height of Bashar al-Assad’s regime. Now, like thousands of other Syrians, he is trying to find clues about what happened, and whether or not his father may still be alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: Rick Steves Refuses to Get Cynical About the World
description: The guidebook writer and television personality reflects on his cancer diagnosis, social media’s corrosive effect on tourism and the transformative power of travel.
content: The guidebook writer and television personality reflects on his cancer diagnosis, social media’s corrosive effect on tourism and the transformative power of travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKinnon de Kuyper
title: South Koreans Celebrate the President’s Impeachment in Seoul
description: A dozen members of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s own party helped remove him from office. Lawmakers sought to impeach the president after his declaration of martial law drew public outrage.
content: A dozen members of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s own party helped remove him from office. Lawmakers sought to impeach the president after his declaration of martial law drew public outrage.
source.name: The New York Times
